events.title: Crooklyn. 1994. Directed by Spike Lee
events.description: Crooklyn (1994), directed by Spike Lee and co-written with his siblings, is a nostalgic, heartfelt portrait of a young girl’s coming of age in 1970s Fort Greene, Brooklyn. One of Lee’s most personal films, it blends warmth, humor, and striking visuals by Arthur Jafa.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 2 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 2

events.title: La Folie Almayer (Almayer's Folly). 2011. Directed by Chantal Akerman
events.description: La Folie Almayer (2011), Chantal Akerman’s haunting adaptation of Joseph Conrad’s novel, follows a disillusioned European trader and his estranged daughter in Malaysia. Lushly shot and formally bold, the film marked the opening of MoMI’s First Look festival.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 2 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 2

events.title: Met Expert Talks—Sargent and Paris
events.description: Hear new insights and untold stories from Met insiders including curators, scientists, conservators, and scholars and take a closer look at the works of art on view in the galleries.
events.location: The Met Fifth Avenue

events.title: China's Changing Religious Landscape
events.description: Join us for a virtual panel discussion on how China’s religious rejuvenation is reshaping communities and refashioning the relationship between Chinese citizens and the state.
events.location: Online

events.title: OVER THE GREAT WALL, A CENTURY APART
events.description: The Great Wall of Two Williams: Two Journeys, One Century Mission Explorer and author William Lindesay OBE presents the extraordinary story of William Edgar Geil, the first person to traverse and document the entire Great Wall of China. A century after Geil’s death, Lindesay retraces his steps, pairing archival and contemporary photographs to reveal the Wall’s dramatic transformation. This powerful visual lecture honors a lost American legacy and highlights the urgent need for preservation.
events.location: 46 E 70th Street, NY, NY 10021​

events.title: Guelwaar. 1992. Written and directed by Ousmane Sembene
events.description: Guelwaar (1992), a sharp political satire by Ousmane Sembene, explores religious and social tensions in Senegal after a political activist’s body is mistakenly buried in the wrong cemetery. The film opened the inaugural New York African Film Festival.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 2 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 2

events.title: Adieu Philippine. 1962. Directed by Jacques Rozier
events.description: Adieu Philippine (1962), Jacques Rozier’s vibrant French New Wave gem, follows a young TV technician and two aspiring actresses as they navigate youth, romance, and looming military service. A lively, bittersweet portrait of 1960s France.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 2 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 2

events.title: Silent Book Club of Death NYC at The Met Cloisters
events.description: Join the New York City chapter of the Silent Book Club of Death for an afternoon of reading and contemplating mortality.
events.location: The Met Cloisters Gallery 7, Cuxa Cloister

events.title: World Oceans Week 2025
events.description: World Oceans Week 2025 will begin with a celebration of ocean science being done by The Explorers Club and beyond, as well as a celebration of one of the ocean’s staunchest defenders – Her Deepness, Sylvia Earle.
events.location: 46 E 70th Street, NY, NY 10021​

events.title: 35 Rhums (35 Shots of Rum). 2008. Directed by Claire Denis
events.description: 35 Shots of Rum (2008), Claire Denis’s tender tribute to Ozu’s Late Spring, explores the quiet bond between a widowed father and his daughter in Paris. A lyrical, emotionally rich portrait of love, change, and letting go.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 2 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 2

events.title: The Harder They Come. 1972. Directed by Perry Henzell
events.description: The Harder They Come (1972), Jamaica’s first homegrown feature, stars Jimmy Cliff as a singer turned outlaw. With its gritty realism, reggae soundtrack, and anti-hero edge, it became a cult classic and midnight movie sensation.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 2 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 2

events.title: The Big Trail. 1930. Directed by Raoul Walsh
events.description: The Big Trail (1930), John Wayne’s first starring role, is a visually stunning western epic about pioneers on the Oregon Trail. Shot in Fox’s widescreen Grandeur process, Raoul Walsh’s film remains a landmark of early cinematic ambition.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 1 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1

events.title: I Am Not Your Negro. 2016. Directed by Raoul Peck
events.description: I Am Not Your Negro (2016), directed by Raoul Peck and narrated by Samuel L. Jackson, powerfully brings James Baldwin’s unfinished work to life—exploring race in America through the lives of Medgar Evers, Malcolm X, and Martin Luther King Jr.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 2 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 2

events.title: Met Expert Talks at The Met Cloisters—A History of The Met Cloisters
events.description: Join Museum experts for a deep dive into a selection of exhibition objects in the galleries.
events.location: The Met Cloisters Main Hall

events.title: Numéro Deux. 1975. Directed by Jean-Luc Godard
events.description: Numéro Deux (1975), Jean-Luc Godard’s bold experiment in video and film, blends home movie and essay to rethink cinema itself. Politically charged and formally radical, it marked a new phase in Godard’s artistic evolution.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 2 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 2

events.title: Taiyō no Hakaba (The Sun’s Burial).1960. Directed by Nagisa Ōshima
events.description: The Sun’s Burial (1960), directed by Nagisa Ōshima, is a raw, violent portrait of postwar Tokyo’s underclass. A landmark of Japan’s New Wave, it blends chaos and humanism in a bleak vision of social decay.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 2 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 2

events.title: The Harder They Come. 1972. Directed by Perry Henzell
events.description: The Harder They Come (1972), Jamaica’s first feature by Jamaicans, stars Jimmy Cliff as a singer turned outlaw. Fueled by a legendary reggae soundtrack, it became a cult hit and midnight movie staple.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 2 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 2

events.title: Taiga. 1992. Written and directed by Ulrike Ottinger
events.description: Taiga (1992), Ulrike Ottinger’s epic 8.5-hour documentary, immerses viewers in the daily life of Northern Mongolia’s nomadic yak and reindeer herders—a meditative, visually rich reflection on culture, humanity, and the natural world.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 2 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 2

events.title: Permanent Vacation. 1980. Written and directed by Jim Jarmusch
events.description: Permanent Vacation (1980), Jim Jarmusch’s debut feature, is a moody portrait of a drifting teenager in pre-gentrification Soho. Shot in 16mm, it captures the alienation of a post-punk generation with raw, minimalist charm.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 2 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 2

events.title: Senseless. 1961. Directed by Ron Rice The Flower Thief. 1960. Written and directed by Ron Rice
events.description: Ron Rice’s The Flower Thief (1960) and Senseless (1961) are key works of 1960s underground cinema. Shot in 16mm with a Beat sensibility, these poetic, rebellious films capture the spirit of avant-garde filmmaking at its East Village peak.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 2 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 2

events.title: Connecting Collections Summer Institute
events.description: Learn techniques for analyzing and interpreting modern and contemporary art in three New York City art museums.
events.location: The Met Fifth Avenue Bonnie J. Sacerdote Lecture Hall, Ruth and Harold D. Uris Center for Education

events.title: 725 Salon: Chun Wai Chan
events.description: At this special salon event, Chun Wai Chan, the first Chinese principal dancer of the New York City Ballet will perform classic ballet excerpts live and share insights into the movements and emotional expression behind his work and life.
events.location: 725 Park Ave New York, NY 10021

events.title: Tokyo monogatari (Tokyo Story). 1953. Directed by Yasujirō Ozu
events.description: Tokyo Story (1953), Yasujirō Ozu’s quietly devastating tale of aging parents visiting their indifferent children, is a masterwork of emotional restraint and cinematic grace—now hailed as one of the greatest films ever made.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 2 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 2

events.title: Numéro Deux. 1975. Directed by Jean-Luc Godard
events.description: Numéro Deux (1975) is Jean-Luc Godard’s bold blend of video and film—a radical, self-reflective essay on family, media, and cinema itself, marking a break from his early work and a turn toward new visual language.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 2 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 2

events.title: Senseless. 1961. Directed by Ron Rice The Flower Thief. 1960. Written and directed by Ron Rice
events.description: Ron Rice’s The Flower Thief (1960) and Senseless (1961) are playful, Beat-influenced landmarks of underground cinema—freeform 16mm experiments that helped define the East Village’s avant-garde film scene in the early 1960s.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 2 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 2

events.title: A Bad Son and Two Short Films
events.description: L’Alliance New York presents Papillon (2024), Agua (1989), and a new restoration of Claude Sautet’s Un mauvais fils (1980), a gripping portrait of addiction and redemption. Followed by a discussion with curator Jake Perlin and David Schwartz.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 2 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 2

events.title: Charles Sumner: Conscience of a Nation
events.description: Join author Zaakir Tameez in Bryant Park for a fresh look at Charles Sumner—beyond the infamous 1856 caning. Explore his pioneering role in civil rights, his vision of multiracial democracy, and the personal complexities of one of the most passionate reformers of his time. Presented in partnership with the Bryant Park Reading Room.
events.location: This program will be held at the outdoor Reading Room in Bryant Park. The Reading Room is located on the 42nd Street side of the park between 5th and 6th Avenues. Look for the yellow and white umbrellas.

events.title: Taiyō no Hakaba (The Sun’s Burial). 1960. Directed by Nagisa Ōshima
events.description: The Sun’s Burial (1960), Nagisa Ōshima’s explosive early feature, captures postwar Tokyo’s violent underworld with raw energy and bleak humanism—a defining work of Japan’s New Wave.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 2 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 2

events.title: American Hunter. 1988. Directed by Arizal
events.description: American Hunter (1988), Arizal’s wildly over-the-top Indonesian action film starring Chris Mitchum, returns in a rare 35mm print. A cult favorite at Spectacle, it’s a delirious explosion of stunts, chaos, and low-budget brilliance.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 2 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 2

events.title: America at 250: The Battle of Brooklyn
events.description: The 250th anniversary of the American Revolution has begun! Learn about free resources that support teaching New York's important contributions to the war fo independence to prepare for the commemoration of this momentous occasion, Participants will receive 1 CTLE hour
events.location: Zoom

events.title: Met Expert Talks—The New Art: American Photography, 1839–1910
events.description: Join Museum experts for a deep dive into a selection of exhibition objects in the galleries.
events.location: The Met Fifth Avenue Gallery 691, The Charles Z. Offin Gallery

events.title: American Hunter. 1988. Directed by Arizal
events.description: American Hunter (1988), Arizal’s wildly over-the-top Indonesian action film starring Chris Mitchum, returns in a rare 35mm print. A cult favorite at Spectacle, it’s a delirious explosion of stunts, chaos, and low-budget brilliance.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 2 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 2

events.title: Que Dios me perdone (May God Forgive Me). 1948. Directed by Tito Davison
events.description: May God Forgive Me (1948) stars María Félix in a gripping noir-tinged espionage tale set in WWII-era Mexico City, showcasing her range in a dual role and reflecting the era’s global tensions and cinematic style.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 1 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1

events.title: Artist Demos: Weaving
events.description: Learn creative techniques in live, artist-led demonstrations and make art in a relaxed drop-in session in the Creativity Lab. Get inspired and try your hand at weaving with Cynthia Alberto’s approach to zero-waste weaving. Together, we’ll activate looms connected to ancestral traditions.
events.location: MoMA, Floor 2, Creativity Lab The Paula and James Crown Creativity Lab

events.title: New York Historical Summer!
events.description: Spend your Friday evenings with us this July! The New York Historical is celebrating the summer with live music.
events.location: 1st floor, Robert H. and Clarice Smith New York Gallery of American History at The New York Historical, 170 Central Park West, New York, NY 10024

events.title: Met Expert Talks at The Met Cloisters—A History of The Met Cloisters
events.description: Join Museum experts for a deep dive into a selection of exhibition objects in the galleries.
events.location: The Met Cloisters Main Hall

events.title: Date Night—Sargent and Paris
events.description: Join us for a lively evening of performances, art making, and chats inspired by the exhibition Sargent and Paris.
events.location: The Met Fifth Avenue Various locations, Floors 1 and 2

events.title: The Observant Eye
events.description: Slow down, tap into your powers of observation, and discover a work of art through close looking and discussion.
events.location: The Met Fifth Avenue Meet in Carson Family Hall, Ruth and Harold D. Uris Center for Education

events.title: Enamorada (In Love). 1946. Directed by Emilio Fernández
events.description: Enamorada (1946), a landmark of Mexico’s Golden Age, stars María Félix as a fiery aristocrat and Pedro Armendáriz as the revolutionary who challenges her world, in Emilio Fernández’s lush, romantic tale inspired by The Taming of the Shrew.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 1 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1

events.title: La diosa arrodillada (The Kneeling Goddess). 1947. Directed by Roberto Gavaldón
events.description: The Kneeling Goddess (1947) is a noir-inflected melodrama starring María Félix as a captivating model at the center of a destructive love triangle, blending art, obsession, and tragedy in Roberto Gavaldón’s haunting tale of desire and guilt.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 1 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1

events.title: El peñón de las ánimas (The Rock of Souls). 1942. Directed by Miguel Zacarías
events.description: The Rock of Souls (1942) marks María Félix’s film debut, starring alongside Jorge Negrete in a ranchero melodrama of love and family rivalry—an early glimpse of the commanding presence that would make her a Mexican cinema icon.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 1 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1

events.title: La mujer de todos (Everybody’s Woman). 1946. Directed by Julio Bracho
events.description: Everybody’s Woman (1946) features María Félix as a complex heroine in Julio Bracho’s adaptation of La dame aux camélias, reimagined during the Mexican Revolution to explore love, sacrifice, and societal expectations of women.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 1 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1

events.title: Jesse Krimes: Corrections
events.description: Photography has played a key role in structuring systems of power in society, including those related to crime and punishment. This exhibition presents immersive contemporary installations by the artist Jesse Krimes (American, b. 1982) alongside nineteenth-century photographs from The Met collection by the French criminologist Alphonse Bertillon, who developed the first modern system of criminal identification before the adoption of fingerprinting. Krimes’s image-based installations, made over the course of his six-year incarceration, reflect the ingenuity of an artist working without access to traditional materials. Employing prison-issued soap, hair gel, playing cards, and newspaper he created works of art that seek to disrupt and recontextualize the circulation of photographs in the media. Displayed at The Met in dialogue with Bertillon, whose pioneering method paired anthropomorphic measurements with photographs to produce the present-day mug shot, Krimes’s work raises questions about the perceived neutrality of our systems of identification and the hierarchies of social imbalance they create and reinscribe. An artist for whom collaboration and activism are vital, Krimes founded the Center for Art and Advocacy to highlight the talent and creative potential among individuals who have experienced incarceration and to support and improve outcomes for formerly incarcerated artists. The exhibition is made possible by Joyce Frank Menschel.
events.location: The Met Fifth Avenue in Gallery 851

events.title: Río Escondido (Hidden River). 1948. Directed by Emilio Fernández
events.description: In Río Escondido (1948), María Félix plays a devoted teacher confronting corruption in a remote village, offering a powerful portrait of post-revolutionary ideals in Emilio Fernández’s political allegory—visually striking and deeply patriotic.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 1 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1

events.title: Doña Bárbara. 1943. Directed by Fernando de Fuentes
events.description: In Doña Bárbara (1943), María Félix commands the screen as a fierce landowner shaped by trauma, in a landmark role that earned her the title "La Doña" and redefined the image of female power in Latin American cinema.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 1 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1

events.title: Maclovia. 1948. Directed by Emilio Fernández
events.description: Maclovia (1948) Set on Janitzio Island, Maclovia follows a forbidden romance between a young woman (María Félix) and a fisherman amid family resistance and military oppression. Directed by Emilio Fernández and shot by Gabriel Figueroa, the film blends striking visuals with social critique, exploring Indigenous life and state power in post-revolutionary Mexico.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 1 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1

events.title: Tizoc. 1957. Directed by Ismael Rodriguez
events.description: Tizoc (1957) In their only film together, María Félix and Pedro Infante star in this tragic romance between a European-descended woman and a Mixtec Indigenous man, exploring themes of love and racial prejudice. Directed by Ismael Rodríguez, Tizoc earned international acclaim, including a Golden Globe and a Silver Bear for Infante’s performance.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 1 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1

events.title: French Cancan. 1954.Directed by Jean Renoir
events.description: French Cancan (1954) – Jean Renoir’s Technicolor musical set in Belle Époque Paris stars María Félix as a Spanish dancer opposite Jean Gabin and Édith Piaf. A dazzling blend of romance, performance, and Parisian spectacle.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 1 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1

events.title: Doña Diabla. 1950. Directed by Tito Daviso
events.description: Doña Diabla (1950) – María Félix stars as a scorned divorcée who turns seduction into revenge—until her daughter falls for the wrong man. A gripping noir melodrama that earned Félix her third Ariel Award and a spot at Cannes.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 1 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1

events.title: Pioneering Scientific Voices: Women and STEM
events.description: Women have been making breakthroughs in STEM fields throughout US history. Discover some of these women’s stories and learn ways to share their inspiring contributions with your students.
events.location: Zoom

events.title: Illiberal America: A History
events.description: Pulitzer Prize–winning historian Steven Hahn (NYU) traces the long arc of American illiberalism—from Native removal and Reconstruction to the January 6 Capitol insurrection. Presented by the New-York Historical Society in partnership with the Bryant Park Reading Room.
events.location: This program will be held at the outdoor Reading Room in Bryant Park. The Reading Room is located on the 42nd Street side of the park between 5th and 6th Avenues. Look for the yellow and white umbrellas.

events.title: Dispatches from the Field: Alison Criscitiello
events.description: Dispatches from the Field, a new digital program designed to bring The Explorers Club community closer—wherever you are. Each session.

events.title: La mujer sin alma (The Woman Without a Soul). 1944. Directed by Fernando de Fuentes
events.description: La mujer sin alma (1944) – María Félix plays a working-class beauty who climbs the social ladder by seducing and discarding wealthy men. A sharp melodrama about ambition, power, and class, directed by Fernando de Fuentes.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 1 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1

events.title: Amok. 1944. Directed by Antonio Momplet
events.description: Amok (1944) – In this tropical melodrama based on Stefan Zweig’s novel, María Félix plays dual roles that haunt a troubled surgeon spiraling into madness. A rare globe-trotting production for Mexican cinema’s Golden Age, featuring a score by Agustín Lara.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 1 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1

events.title: Writing Club: On Jack Whitten, with Jazzy Charles and Antoinette Cooper
events.description: Jazzy Charles and Antoinette Cooper facilitate this Writing Club focusing on works by Jack Whitten currently on view in the exhibition Jack Whitten: The Messenger. Inspired by these three artists’ approaches to abstraction, we’ll explore writing and music as a means of investigating and experiencing the ineffable nature of Whitten’s work. This session will take place in-person at MoMA.
events.location: MoMA, Floor 6

events.title: Río Escondido (Hidden River). 1948. Directed by Emilio Fernández
events.description: Río Escondido (1948) – María Félix stars as a determined schoolteacher sent to a remote village in this powerful political allegory directed by Emilio Fernández. A landmark of post-revolutionary Mexican cinema, featuring stunning cinematography by Gabriel Figueroa and a rare presidential cameo.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 1 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1

events.title: Que Dios me perdone (May God Forgive Me). 1948. Directed by Tito Davison
events.description: Que Dios me perdone (1948) – In this noir-tinged WWII espionage thriller set in Mexico City, María Félix plays a mysterious woman with dual identities at the center of international intrigue. Directed by Tito Davison with a script by José Revueltas, the film blends psychological tension with political shadows.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 1 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1

events.title: New York Historical Summer!
events.description: Spend your Friday evenings with us this July! The New York Historical is celebrating the summer with live music.
events.location: 1st floor, Robert H. and Clarice Smith New York Gallery of American History at The New York Historical, 170 Central Park West, New York, NY 10024

events.title: Met Expert Talks at The Met Cloisters—A History of The Met Cloisters
events.description: Join Museum experts for a deep dive into a selection of exhibition objects in the galleries.
events.location: The Met Cloisters Main Hall

events.title: La diosa arrodillada (The Kneeling Goddess). 1947. Directed by Roberto Gavaldón
events.description: La diosa arrodillada (The Kneeling Goddess) (1947) – María Félix stars in Roberto Gavaldón’s lush noir melodrama as a model whose likeness in a sculpture sets off a deadly spiral of desire and betrayal. A tale of obsession and moral ambiguity, driven by Félix’s commanding performance.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 1 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1

events.title: Enamorada (In Love). 1946. Directed by Emilio Fernández
events.description: In this classic of Mexican Golden Age cinema, María Félix stars as a fiery aristocrat whose world is upended by a revolutionary general. Emilio Fernández’s sweeping romantic drama pairs sharp performances with stunning visuals by Gabriel Figueroa.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 1 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1

events.title: El peñón de las ánimas (The Rock of Souls). 1942. Directed by Miguel Zacarías
events.description: María Félix makes her screen debut as a woman torn between love and a family feud in this ranchero melodrama opposite Jorge Negrete. A pivotal first step toward her legendary status as “La Doña.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 1 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1

events.title: Doña Bárbara. 1943. Directed by Fernando de Fuentes
events.description: María Félix cemented her star persona as “La Doña” in this landmark adaptation of Rómulo Gallegos’ novel. As a fierce landowner shaped by trauma, she redefined the Latin American female protagonist with power, complexity, and unforgettable presence.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 1 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1

events.title: The New Art: American Photography, 1839–1910
events.description: This exhibition presents a bold new history of American photography from the medium’s birth in 1839 to the first decade of the 20th century. Drawn from The Met’s William L. Schaeffer Collection, major works by lauded artists such as Josiah Johnson Hawes, John Moran, Carleton Watkins, and Alice Austen are shown in dialogue with extraordinary photographs by obscure or unknown practitioners made in small towns and cities from coast to coast. Featuring a range of formats, from daguerreotypes and cartes de visite to stereographs and cyanotypes, the show explores the dramatic change in the nation’s sense of itself that was driven by the immediate success of photography as a cultural, commercial, artistic, and psychological preoccupation. In 1835, even before the nearly simultaneous announcement of the invention of the new art in Paris and London, the American philosopher essayist Ralph Waldo Emerson noted with remarkable vision: “Our Age is Ocular.” The exhibition is made possible by the Diane W. and James E. Burke Fund and the Diane Carol Brandt Fund. Additional support is provided by the Horace W. Goldsmith Foundation.
events.location: The Met Fifth Avenue in Gallery 851

events.title: Maclovia. 1948. Directed by Emilio Fernández
events.description: Set on Janitzio Island, this poignant love story stars María Félix as a young Purépecha woman torn between tradition, family, and power. A visually stunning collaboration between Emilio Fernández and cinematographer Gabriel Figueroa, the film blends romance and social critique at the height of Mexican Golden Age cinema.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 1 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1

events.title: Tizoc. 1957. Directed by Ismael Rodriguez
events.description: In their only on-screen pairing, legends María Félix and Pedro Infante star in this poignant tale of forbidden love between a Mixtec man and a woman of European descent. A landmark of Mexican cinema, Tizoc earned global acclaim, including a Golden Globe and Berlin’s Silver Bear.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 1 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1

events.title: French Cancan. 1954. Directed by Jean Renoir
events.description: Jean Renoir’s Technicolor tribute to Belle Époque Paris stars María Félix as a fiery Spanish dancer entangled in love and showbiz with impresario Jean Gabin. A dazzling musical drama featuring Édith Piaf, the film showcases Félix’s international range and Renoir’s vibrant artistry.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 1 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1

events.title: La mujer de todos (Everybody’s Woman). 1946. Directed by Julio Bracho
events.description: In this adaptation of La dame aux camélias, María Félix stars as María Romano, a complex woman navigating love and societal judgment during the Mexican Revolution. Directed by Julio Bracho, the film highlights Félix’s emotional range and the evolving roles of women in times of upheaval.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 1 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1

events.title: Met Expert Talks en español—La herencia cultural de la talavera poblana
events.description: Observe cerca las obras de arte y escuche de primera mano a los especialistas del Met.
events.location: The Met Fifth Avenue Gallery 774, Henry R. Luce Center for the Study of American Art

events.title: Met Expert Talks—The Roof Garden Commission: Jennie C. Jones, Ensemble
events.description: Join Museum experts for a deep dive into a selection of exhibition objects in the galleries.
events.location: The Met Fifth Avenue Gallery 926, The Iris and B. Gerald Cantor Roof Garden

events.title: Baseball Cards from the Collection of Jefferson R. Burdick
events.description: The Jefferson R. Burdick collection of ephemera at The Met contains one of the most distinguished collections of historical baseball cards anywhere in the world. In 1947, Burdick (1900–1963), an electrician from Syracuse, New York, and avid collector of ephemera, began to donate in large batches his holdings of more than 300,000 trade cards, postcards, and posters to the Museum. Included in the donation were more than 30,000 baseball cards dating back to the 1880s. This exhibition features over one hundred cards dating from 1895 to 1956. Produced using a variety of printing techniques and in a range of styles, the cards feature legends of the game from a bygone era.
events.location: The Met Fifth Avenue in Gallery 774A

events.title: The U.S.-ROK Alliance in 2025 and Global Implications
events.description: Join the Asia Society and the Korea Foundation for a two-part program assessing the current state and the future of the U.S.-ROK alliance under new leaders, and the implications for the Indo-Pacific region.
events.location: 725 Park Avenue New York, NY 10021

events.title: Doña Diabla. 1950. Directed by Tito Daviso
events.description: Doña Diabla (1950) – After a bitter divorce, Ángela (María Félix) makes heartbreak her revenge—until her past catches up with her in the form of her daughter’s suitor. A stylish, emotionally charged melodrama that earned Félix her third Ariel Award and a Cannes slot for director Tito Davison.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 1 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1

events.title: La mujer sin alma (The Woman Without a Soul). 1944. Directed by Fernando de Fuentes
events.description: In this sharp melodrama of ambition and desire, María Félix plays a working-class beauty who climbs the social ladder by seducing and discarding powerful men. Directed by Fernando de Fuentes, the film offers a riveting portrait of class, power, and calculated survival.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 1 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1

events.title: Teacher Workshop - Blacklisted: An American Story
events.description: In 1947, the House Un-American Activities Committee (HUAC) published a famous Blacklist which severely damaged or ended the career of several artists from Hollywood and beyond based on their allegedly “subversive” political views. Explore a brand new exhibition that tells this important story and which reflects on what it meant to be an American in the mid-20th century.

events.title: Lincoln’s Lady Spymaster: The Untold Story of the Abolitionist Southern Belle Who Helped Win the Civil War
events.description: Journalist Gerri Willis uncovers the daring espionage of Elizabeth Van Lew, a Southern belle who led a covert spy network for the Union during the Civil War. Presented by the New-York Historical Society in partnership with the Bryant Park Reading Room.
events.location: This program will be held at the outdoor Reading Room in Bryant Park. The Reading Room is located on the 42nd Street side of the park between 5th and 6th Avenues. Look for the yellow and white umbrellas.

events.title: Enamorada (In Love). 1946.Directed by Emilio Fernández
events.description: In this Golden Age classic, María Félix stars as a fiery aristocrat whose world is upended by a revolutionary general (Pedro Armendáriz). Loosely inspired by The Taming of the Shrew, Emilio Fernández’s lush romance blends political ideals, national pride, and passionate conflict—shot with iconic beauty by Gabriel Figueroa.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 1 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1

events.title: Amok. 1944. Directed by Antonio Momplet
events.description: In this fevered adaptation of Stefan Zweig’s novella, María Félix plays a double role that haunts a disgraced Parisian surgeon (Julián Soler) as he flees to colonial India. Directed by Spanish émigré Antonio Momplet and scored by Agustín Lara, the film blends noir melodrama and tropical delirium on an unusually international scale for 1940s Mexican cinema.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 1 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1

events.title: Writing Club at Home: On Jack Whitten, with Jazzy Charles and Antoinette Cooper
events.description: Jazzy Charles and Antoinette Cooper facilitate this Writing Club focusing on works by Jack Whitten currently on view in the exhibition Jack Whitten: The Messenger. Inspired by these three artists’ approaches to abstraction, we’ll explore writing and music as a means of investigating and experiencing the ineffable nature of Whitten’s work. This session will take place online via Zoom.
events.location: Online

events.title: Gallery Tour: Robert Caro in the Museum
events.description: Discover the work and career of American journalist and author Robert A. Caro on a docent-led guided tour of twa installations.
events.location: The New York Historical, 170 Central Park West, New York, NY 10024

events.title: Tizoc. 1957. Directed by Ismael Rodriguez
events.description: The only screen pairing of María Félix and Pedro Infante, this tragic romance follows an Indigenous Mixtec man and a European-descended woman whose love is challenged by deep-rooted prejudice. A landmark of Mexican cinema, Tizoc won the Golden Globe for Best Foreign Language Film and earned Infante the Silver Bear for Best Actor at Berlin.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 1 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1

events.title: Río Escondido (Hidden River). 1948. Directed by Emilio Fernández
events.description: María Félix stars as a devoted schoolteacher sent to a remote village to carry out Mexico’s post-revolutionary educational mission. A bold political allegory directed by Emilio Fernández, the film blends visual grandeur with social critique—and earned Félix her second Ariel Award for Best Actress.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 1 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1

events.title: New York Historical Summer!
events.description: Spend your Friday evenings with us this July! The New York Historical is celebrating the summer with live music.
events.location: 1st floor, Robert H. and Clarice Smith New York Gallery of American History at The New York Historical, 170 Central Park West, New York, NY 10024

events.title: Doña Bárbara. 1943. Directed by Fernando de Fuentes
events.description: María Félix became “La Doña” in this landmark adaptation of Rómulo Gallegos’ novel, playing a fierce landowner shaped by trauma and vengeance. A defining role in Latin American cinema, it launched Félix as a symbol of female autonomy and power.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 1 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1

events.title: La diosa arrodillada (The Kneeling Goddess). 1947. Directed by Roberto Gavaldón
events.description: In this noir-inflected melodrama, María Félix plays a model whose sculpted likeness ignites a deadly love triangle. Directed by Roberto Gavaldón, the film explores desire, guilt, and the fatal consequences of obsession.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 1 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1

events.title: Memorial – Bruce Blanchard ME’78
events.description: Please join The Explorers Club, The Explorers Club Washington Group, and friends and family to celebrate and honor the life of Bruce Blanchard, medalist, former treasurer of the club, and fellow explorer. The reception will take place from 2-4:30 PM on July 26th, at Explorers Club Headquarters in New York City. Please use the form below to RSVP.
events.location: Explorers Club Headquarters in New York City

events.title: Maclovia. 1948. Directed by Emilio Fernández
events.description: María Félix stars in this tragic romance set in a Purépecha village, where love, tradition, and power collide. Directed by Emilio Fernández, with stunning cinematography by Gabriel Figueroa.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 1 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1

events.title: French Cancan. 1954. Directed by Jean Renoir
events.description: Jean Renoir’s Technicolor tribute to Belle Époque Paris stars María Félix as a fiery Spanish dancer entangled in love and showbiz. With Jean Gabin and Édith Piaf.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 1 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1

events.title: Berlin: Die Sinfonie der Großstadt (Berlin: Symphony of a Great City). 1927. Directed by Walter Ruttmann
events.description: Walter Ruttmann’s hypnotic silent classic captures a single day in Weimar-era Berlin through kinetic montage and a roving camera, blending documentary realism with avant-garde rhythm.
events.location: MoMA, Floor 1, Sculpture Garden The Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Sculpture Garden

events.title: Conceptualizing the Constitution
events.description: The U.S. Constitution is the oldest written charter of government still in use today and has long been the subject of pride as well as conflict. Join this workshop to explore the history of the U.S. Constitution as well as instructional strategies for teaching your students to be informed, engaged and active participants in American democracy.
events.location: Zoom

events.title: Religion in the Lands that Became America: A New History
events.description: Historian Thomas A. Tweed explores 10,000 years of spiritual life in North America, tracing Native, African, and European American religious traditions and their lasting influence on the continent’s development. Presented by the New-York Historical Society in partnership with the Bryant Park Reading Room.
events.location: This program will be held at the outdoor Reading Room in Bryant Park. The Reading Room is located on the 42nd Street side of the park between 5th and 6th Avenues. Look for the yellow and white umbrellas.

events.title: The Gold Rush. 1925. Written and directed by Charles Chaplin
events.description: In what he called his greatest film, Charles Chaplin’s Little Tramp braves the Klondike in search of gold, love, and survival. This newly restored 1925 silent version brings fresh clarity to iconic scenes like the shoe dinner and the dance of the dinner rolls—highlighting Chaplin’s unmatched blend of comedy and pathos.
events.location: MoMA, Floor T2/T1, Theater 2 The Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 2

events.title: Gallery Tour: Robert Caro in the Museum
events.description: Discover the work and career of American journalist and author Robert A. Caro on a docent-led guided tour of Robert Caro’s The Power Broker at 50 and “Turn Every Page”: Inside the Robert A Caro.
events.location: The New York Historical, 170 Central Park West, New York, NY 10024

events.title: Gallery Tour: New York and the Art Students League
events.description: Join experienced docents and dive into the lasting impact of the Art Students League, whose alumni include Norman Rockwell, Mark Rothko, Georgia O'Keeffe, and Jacob Lawrence.
events.location: The New York Historical, 170 Central Park West, New York, NY 10024
